sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: 1200 mg IV infused over 3 hours as a single dose

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy are not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: Dosage adjustments are not needed in patients with mild or moderate impairment; severe renal impairment has not been studied
  • hepatic impairment: Dosage adjustments are not needed in patients with mild or moderate impairment; severe hepatic impairment has not been studied
  • geriatric: Dosage adjustments are not needed
  • infusion reaction: Slow the rate or interrupt the infusion

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to oritavancin or components of the product
  • unfractionated heparin sodium use within 48 hours of oritavancin administration; aPTT test results remain falsely elevated for approximately 48 hours after oritavancin infusion

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea has been reported, including cases occurring more than 2 months after administration; evaluate and institute appropriate medical management if suspected or confirmed
  • Hematologic:
  • -- artificially prolongs aPTT for 48 hours and the prothrombin time and INR for 24 hours by binding to and preventing action of the phospholipid reagents which activate coagulation in commonly used laboratory coagulation tests
  • -- if aPTT monitoring within 48 hours of dosing is needed, a non-phospholipid dependent coagulation test such as a Factor Xa (chromogenic) assay or an alternative anticoagulant not requiring aPTT monitoring may be considered
  • -- effects on activated clotting time expected since phospholipid reagents are also used in this test; oritavancin has no effect on the coagulation system
  • Immunologic:
  • -- serious hypersensitivity reactions have been reported; discontinue immediately if an allergic reaction occurs
  • -- previous hypersensitivity reaction to glycopeptides may cause cross-sensitivity; monitoring recommended
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- osteomyelitis has been reported; monitor and institute appropriate medical management if suspected or confirmed
  • Other:
  • -- infusion-related reactions, including pruritus, urticaria or flushing, have been reported; consider slowing or interrupting the infusion if a reaction occurs
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- warfarin

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (9.9%), Vomiting (4.6%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (7.1%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea
  • Hematologic:Activated partial thromboplastin time abnormal, Bleeding, INR raised, Prothrombin time increased
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (less than 1.5%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Osteomyelitis (less than 1.5%)
  • Other:Complication of infusion (1.9%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Oritavancin is a semisynthetic lipoglycopeptide antibacterial agent with bactericidal activity against Gram-positive microorganisms. Bactericidal activity occurs by: inhibition of transglycosylation (polymerization) of cell wall biosynthesis via oritavancin binding to the stem peptide of peptidoglycan precursors. Oritavancin also inhibits the transpeptidation (crosslinking) step of cell wall biosynthesis by binding to cell wall peptide bridge segments, and disrupts the bacterial membrane integrity, which causes depolarization and permeabilization and cell death. Bactericidal activity of oritavancin is concentration dependent.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• not metabolized
  • inhibitor of 1A2, 2B6, 2D6, 2C9, 2C19, and 3A4
  • inducer of CYP3A4 and 2D6

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal: Less than 1% unchanged
  • Renal: Less than 5% unchanged
  • Dialyzable: No (hemodialysis)
  • Total body clearance: 0.445 L/hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • use 3 vials for a 1200 mg dose
  • reconstitute each vial with 40 mL of sterile water for injection to produce concentration of 10 mg/mL/vial
  • swirl gently to avoid foaming
  • dilute only with D5W; do not use NS
  • after removing 120 mL from a 1000 mL bag of D5W, add 40 mL from each of the 3 reconstituted vials to yield 1.2 mg/mL
  • do not mix with other drugs, additives, or solutions mixed in NS, or with basic or neutral pH drug solutions
  • combined storage time from dilution and reconstitution must not exceed 6 hours if stored at room temperature or 12 hours if refrigerated at 36 to 46 degrees F
  • do not administer simultaneously via IV lines or common IV ports with drugs or IV solutions mixed in NS
  • if other drugs or solutions are administered sequentially, flush the IV line prior to and after oritavancin
  • infuse over 3 hours

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• microbiological response (eg, cessation of spread or reduction in size of baseline lesion, absence of fever) or clinical response (eg, reduction in erythema, induration, purulent drainage, fluctuance, pain, tenderness, local heat or warmth) is indicative of efficacy
  • hypersensitivity reactions; increased risk in patients with a history of glycopeptide allergy
  • signs or symptoms of osteomyelitis

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that serious allergic reactions may occur and require immediate medical attention.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, abscess, or infusion site reaction.
  • Instruct patient to report severe watery or bloody diarrhea even when occurring after discontinuation of oritavancin.
